awd_titl_txt: Late Cenozoic dynamics of the latitudinal biodiversity gradient: Regional extinction, range expansion, and biological attributes
awd_abstract_narration:
The most dramatic biological pattern on Earth, the gradient of increasing diversity of species and major groups from the poles to the tropics, is well-documented but the processes generating and maintaining this pattern remains poorly understood. Understanding the factors behind the latitudinal diversity gradient is crucial for developing a more rigorous picture of the dynamics of biodiversity, and for better management of marine biodiversity informed by history to predict species' responses to future global changes. 

To investigate those processes, this research will inventory the past and present spatial distributions of species in an ecologically and economically important group, the marine bivalves, an ideal target because their excellent fossil record can track the origin, spread, and range-contraction of lineages in response to past episodes of global change. Factors potentially shaping the present-day diversity gradient, such as the rate of environmental change and features of the species themselves, such as food source and body size, will be evaluated by synthesizing museum collections and published records. The work will contribute a large block of data to the public Paleobiology Database, support training of undergraduates and a postdoctoral scholar, and produce on-line educational resources, including a high-school teaching module derived from the research.

por.por_cntn:
The latitudinal diversity gradient (LDG) is the most pervasive large-scale biological pattern on Earth, with groups as disparate as flowering plants and sea urchins showing a dramatic rise in species numbers from the poles to the tropics. The LDG has been documented and debated for 250 years, but no consensus has been reached on the origins and maintenance of this dramatic biodiversity trend, or on the drivers of other key features associated with that trend, such as latitudinal shifts in ecological variety (“functional diversity” – the basis for healthy ecosystems). This project integrated biodiversity patterns in time and space using one of the few groups with such a rich fossil record that it could be assessed not just for species numbers but for form and function, to track the dynamics of the LDG over time: the marine bivalves (mussels, oysters, scallops, cockles, and their relatives).

A critical question about the LDG is whether the tropics are “a cradle or a museum of biodiversity” – do low latitudes harbor so many species and evolutionary lineages because more originate there, or because they accumulate there owing to lower extinction rates than at higher latitudes? This long-standing question proved to be a false dichotomy. For the past 15 million years, new lineages originated in the tropics and spread towards both poles, producing a remarkably symmetrical geographic pattern in the ages of bivalve genera (evolutionary lineages of related species), with many young lineages in the tropics, few young lineages in each polar ocean, and a long tail of old lineages in all three regions. Thus, for millions of years the tropics have been both the engine of biodiversity and its greatest accumulator.

We then found that functional diversity also declines toward the poles, but the apportionment of species within the remaining functional types becomes more even. Global patterns of functional diversity in marine (=bivalves) and terrestrial (=birds) systems proved to be remarkably similar, suggesting that for land and sea, high tropical species diversity reflects a high degree of ecological specialization within a few functional types and/or factors that drive much higher origination rates (or much lower extinction rates) in the small set of hyper-rich functional types in the tropics. Tracking the dynamics back into the fossil record, we found a striking contrast in the relation of functional and taxonomic diversity across latitude today (up to 80% drop in species numbers, up to 70% drop in functional diversity) compared to major extinction events (up to 80% drop in species numbers, but only 0-10% drop in functional diversity). This finding opens new research directions: will extinctions currently being driven by human activities produce a concomitant drop in functional diversity, with potentially severe ecological consequences, or will human pressures cut species numbers but leave functional diversity relatively intact?

We made and analyzed 3D scans of bivalve shell form to complement the spatial data on species numbers and functional diversity, finding another striking pattern: the shift to plainer shells at high latitudes occurs by dropping out of evolutionary lineages taxa rather than by transformation of individual species as might be expected if predation against weakly defended species was driving the pattern, as most have predicted.

Analyses of bivalve diversity are not just of academic interest: bivalves are a key source of protein, directly or indirectly, for billions of people globally. However, only a handful of species have been assessed for extinction risk in today’s oceans. We developed a predictive model, verified against survival patterns in the fossil record, to map intrinsic extinction risk across all marine bivalves, and across the continental shelves of the world, allowing us to pinpoint regional faunas and species of likely concern for management and conservation. The tropical east Atlantic and the temperate northeast and southeast Pacific are especially rich in exploited species having high intrinsic vulnerability. We developed a high-school education module on this work in collaboration with Berkeley's Understanding Evolution group.

To date, the project has produced 27 papers and book chapters with 5 more currently in review, and 35 conference abstracts with 7 more submitted to this summer’s North American Paleontological Convention. More than 500 3D images and supporting data have been uploaded to the public website Morphosource. Four graduate students, six undergraduates, and two postdoctoral scholars have received training and mentoring in biodiversity analyses and evolutionary paleobiology; all four graduate students, three undergraduates, and both postdocs have presented talks at national or international meetings, and that work has been published or will be soon. Four of the undergraduates are now in STEM graduate programs, and one is in the MIT science journalism program. In 2023, education products generated by our group from this and previous "Understanding Evolution" work received 72,626 pageviews by 6373 users. The PI was also featured in a short segment for the “National Geographic Explores” series.
